PT J
AN ZOOR15009048524
DT Article
TI Individual effects of cichlidogyriasis and streptococosis induced on the
   blood biochemistry of tilapia Oreochromis niloticus.
FT Efectos individuales de la ciclidogiriasis y estreptococosis inducidas
   en la bioquimica sanguinea de la tilapia Oreochromis niloticus.
AU Jose Sandoval-Gio, Juan (jsandoval29@hotmail.com) 
   Rosado-Vallado, Miguel
   Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna
SO Hidrobiologica
VL 23
IS 3
PS 328-339
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 10
AB In this study, we propose to evaluate the blood biochemistry as
   diagnosis technique of a pathologic process in tilapias Oreochromis
   niloticus by means of infections induced by Streptococcus sp. or by the
   activation of the immune response induced by antigens of Cichlidogyrus
   spp. Specifically, variations of some metabolites from the blood
   biochemistry were evaluated in experimentally infected tilapia
   Oreochromis niloticus. The organisms were intraperitoneally challenged
   (IP) with individual antigenic extracts of Streptococcus sp. (STREP
   Group, n = 10) and Cichlidogyrus spp. (C-EXP Group, n = 10),
   respectively, while 10 other tilapia were inoculated with a saline
   solution buffer (SS Group) and were used as immunization control.
   Another group of 70 tilapias was maintained in aquaculture conditions
   included the baseline group (LB). The negative control (CN) included 10
   fish free of infection. The blood chemistry (metabolites and ions) were
   tested in a microplate format. No differences were observed between the
   LB and the CN groups (p > 0.05). Only fish injected with Streptococcus
   sp. (STREP) and Cichlidogyrus spp. (C-EXP) were significantly different
   with the values of glucose, total proteins, albumin, and globulins, when
   comparing with LB fish (p < 0.05). Furthermore, the cholesterol, calcium
   and the chlorine changed significantly in the STREP fish (p > 0.05). The
   results from the induced infections with Streptococcus sp. and
   Cichlidogyrus spp., respectively, modified some parameters of the blood
   biochemistry of tilapia that could be used for some preliminary
   diagnosis of infectious diseases.
C1 Jose Sandoval-Gio, Juan; Inst Politecn Nacl CINVESTAV IPN, Ctr Invest &
   Estudios Avanzados, Carretera Antigua Progreso Km 6,AP-73 Cordemex,
   Merida, Yucatan, 97310, Mexico, Mexico.
EM jsandoval29@hotmail.com
RI del Pilar Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna/AAH-1895-2020; sandoval-gio,
   juan/F-4094-2019
OI del Pilar Rodriguez-Canul, Rossanna/0000-0003-0469-1489; Rosado Vallado,
   Miguel Enrique/0000-0002-9272-0755; sandoval-gio,
   juan/0000-0001-7218-082X
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Pathology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology;
   Hematology; Infectious Diseases
SN 0188-8897
BD Techniques; Pathological techniques; Biochemistry; Circulatory system;
   Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Diseases and disorders; Microbial diseases

   chemistry]. 
   Oreochromis niloticus [Diagnostic techniques /  / ] [Biochemistry /

   Cichlidogyrus / ] [Bacterial diseases / Streptococcus / ].

   Perciformes, Cichlidae, Platyhelminthes, Monogenea

   Cichlidogyrus (Monogenea): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI Condition and Biodiversity of Hard Coral at Gangga Island, North
   Sulawesi.
FT Kondisi dan Keanekaragaman Karang Batu di Perairan Pulau Gangga Sulawesi
   Utara.
AU Souhoka, Jemmy (koral_js@yahoo.com) 
SO Ilmu Kelautan
VL 18
IS 4
PS 213-224
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English; Indonesian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Gangga Island (North Minahasa District, North Sulawesi Province) is
   located at 1[degree]46'19''N-125[degree]03'11'' E. Coral reef ecosystem
   dominated of its coastal areas. Increasing human activities in the area
   is thought to influence the condition of coral reef and its diversity.
   This study aims to observe the condition and biodiversity of hard coral
   in the Gangga Island waters. This study was conducted in May 2011 at 5
   (five) stations, i.e. Station 1 (Lihaga Island), Station 2 (Gangga 1),
   Station 3 (Tindila Island), Station 4 (Panjang Beach) and Station 5
   (Gangga 2). The Line Intercept Transect (LIT) method was applied in this
   study. There were 106 species of hard corals consisting of 16 families
   found in location. The condition of hard corals was classified into
   middle to good, and the persentage of coverage was in between 24.24 -
   73.30 %. Corals at station 1 were in the good location and they have the
   highest diversity index (1.17), while the highest evenness index was at
   Station 3 (0.91). Generally, at Gangga Island, the domination of hard
   coral was 10.958 cm or 43,83 % (depth 3m) and 12.116 cm or 48,46 %
   (depth 6m) of the total transect (25,000 cm) with coral species of
   Acropora sp (2.344 cm) or 9,38 % at depth of 3m and Porites nigrecens
   (3.751 cm) or 15 % was dominant at depth of 6m. Result of this study can
   be used in management coral reef ecosystem policy of the goverment of
   North Sulawesi.
C1 Souhoka, Jemmy; UPT Loka Konservasi Biota Laut Lembaga Ilmu Penge, Jln
   Tandurusa 1, Bitung, Sulawesi Utara, 95527, Indonesia, Indonesia.
EM koral_js@yahoo.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Physiology; Marine &Freshwater
   Biology
SN 0853-7291
BD Animals and man; Whole animal physiology; Habitat; Marine habitat;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Scleractinia [Disturbance by man / Human disturbance / ] [Physiological
   condition /  / ] [Reef habitat /  / ] [North Pacific / Indonesia, North
   Sulawesi, Gangga Island / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia
OR Scleractinia (Zoantharia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103019018
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15103019006

PM 24533316
DT Article
TI Observation of a novel Babesia spp. in Eastern Grey Kangaroos (Macropus
   giganteus) in Australia.
AU Dawood, Kaiser E. (kaiser.dawood@gmail.com) 
   Morgan, Jess A.T.
   Busfield, Frances
   Srivastava, Mukesh
   Fletcher, Taryn I.
   Sambono, Jacqueline
   Jackson, Louise A.
   Venus, Bronwyn
   Philbey, Adrian W.
   Lew-Tabor, Ala E.
SO International Journal for Parasitology Parasites and Wildlife
VL 2
PS 54-61
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The roles and epidemiological features of tick-borne protozoans are not
   well elicited in wildlife. Babesia spp. are documented in many domestic
   animals, including cattle, horses, pigs, dogs and cats. Three cases
   affecting eastern grey kangaroos are described. The kangaroos exhibited
   neurological signs, depression and marked anaemia, and microscopic
   examination of blood smears revealed intraerythrocytic piroplasms. One
   to seven intraerythrocytic spherical, oval, pyriform and
   irregularly-shaped parasites consistent with Babesia spp. were seen in
   the blood smears and the percentage of infected erythrocytes was
   estimated to be approximately 7% in each case. Data suggest that the
   tick vector for this kangaroo Babesia sp. is a Haemaphysalis species.
   For Case 2, ultrastructural examination of the erythrocytes of the renal
   capillaries showed parasites resembling Babesia spp. and 18 of 33
   erythrocytes were infected. DNA sequencing of the amplified 18S rDNA
   confirmed that the observed intraerythrocytic piroplasms belong to the
   genus Babesia. The phylogenetic position of this new kangaroo Babesia
   sp. (de novo Babesia macropus), as a sister species to the new
   Australian woylie Babesia sp., suggests a close affinity to the
   described Afro-Eurasian species Babesia orientalis and Babesia occultans
   suggesting perhaps a common ancestor for the Babesia in kangaroos. (C)
   2012 Australian Society for Parasitology Published by Elsevier Ltd. Open
   access under CC BY-NC-ND license.
C1 Dawood, Kaiser E.; Charles Sturt Univ, Sch Anim & Vet Sci, Wagga Wagga,
   NSW, 2678, Australia, Australia.
EM kaiser.dawood@gmail.com
RI Lew-Tabor, Ala/A-5286-2010; Venus, Bronwyn/C-1859-2017
OI Lew-Tabor, Ala/0000-0001-7147-1078; Jackson, Louise/0000-0002-8677-2989;
   Venus, Bronwyn/0000-0003-2981-5353
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 2213-2244
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia;
   Australia
DE Babesia macropus [Mammalian hosts / Macropus giganteus / New parasite
   species] [ /  / New South Wales & Queensland] [New South Wales /  / New
   species from mammalian host] [Queensland /  / ]. 
   Macropus giganteus [Protozoan parasites / Babesia macropus / New
   parasite species] [ /  / New South Wales & Queensland] [New South Wales
   /  / New protozoan parasite species] [Queensland /  / ].

PT J

PM 24533324
DT Article
TI A Nearctic parasite in a Palearctic host: Parelaphostrongylus andersoni
   (Nematoda; Protostrongylidae) infecting semi-domesticated reindeer in
   Alaska.
AU Verocai, Guilherme G. (gui.verocai@ucalgary.ca) 
   Lejeune, Manigandan
   Finstad, Greg L.
   Kutz, Susan J.
SO International Journal for Parasitology Parasites and Wildlife
VL 2
PS 119-123
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Parelaphostrongylus andersoni is a muscle-dwelling protostrongylid
   nematode that infects caribou and white-tailed deer across North
   America, and can cause significant muscular and pulmonary pathology in
   these species. We collected 44 fecal samples from semi-domesticated
   reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) from the Kakarak herd of western
   Seward Peninsula, Alaska, USA. This herd has no record of historical
   contact and extremely limited possibility of contemporary contact with
   native Grant's caribou (Rangifer tarandus granti) of the Western Arctic
   herd. Fecal samples were processed using the Baermann technique, and
   22.7% (n = 10) were positive for protostrongylid dorsal-spined larvae
   (DSL). Genomic DNA extracted from individual DSL from each of the ten
   positive reindeer (total of 48 DSL) was amplified by PCR targeting the
   ITS-2 region of ribosomal RNA. Forty of 48 DSL were successfully
   sequenced and confirmed as P. andersoni and one representative sequence
   for each of the ten positive samples was deposited in GenBank. No other
   protostrongylids, including Varestrongylus sp., presumed to be
   widespread across caribou range, and Elaphostrongylus rangiferi, which
   could have been introduced with reindeer from Eurasia, were detected in
   these samples. P. andersoni is likely widespread among introduced
   reindeer in Alaska, potentially causing subtle but deleterious effects
   with negative economic impacts on commercial herding activities. (C)
   2013 Australian Society for Parasitology Published by Elsevier Ltd. Open
   access under CC BY-NC-ND license.
C1 Verocai, Guilherme G.; Univ Calgary, Fac Vet Med, 3330 Hosp Dr NW,
   Calgary, AB, T2N 4N1, Canada, Canada.
EM gui.verocai@ucalgary.ca
OI kutz, susan/0000-0003-2352-8687
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Parasitology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 2213-2244
BD Biochemistry; Nutrition; Digestion; Defaecation; Genetics; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of dispersal; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA
DE Parelaphostrongylus andersoni [Nucleic acids / rRNA gene sequences / new
   record; prevalence] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Mammalian hosts /
   Rangifer tarandus tarandus / ] [Alaska / Seward Peninsula, Teller town /
   ]. 
   Rangifer tarandus tarandus [Faeces /  / new record; prevalence;
   semi-domesticated condition] [Nematode parasites / Parelaphostrongylus
   andersoni / ] [Introduction /  / ] [Alaska / Seward Peninsula, Teller
   town / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Ungulates; Vertebrates

   Nematoda
OR Rangifer tarandus tarandus (Cervidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Parelaphostrongylus andersoni (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15309053769
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published

AN ZOOR15309053770
PM 24533325
DT Article
TI Severe glomerular disease in juvenile grey snapper Lutjanus griseus L.
   in the Gulf of Mexico caused by the myxozoan Sphaerospora motemarini n.
   sp.
AU Holzer, Astrid S. (astrid.holzer@paru.cas.cz) 
   Peckova, Hanka
   Patra, Sneha
   Brennan, Nathan P.
   Yanes-Roca, Carlos
   Main, Kevan L.
SO International Journal for Parasitology Parasites and Wildlife
VL 2
PS 124-130
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB In the eastern Gulf of Mexico, off the coast of Florida, grey snapper,
   Lutjanus griseus was found to be infected with the myxozoan parasite
   Sphaerospora motemarini n. sp., with high prevalence (83%) and intensity
   of infection occuring in age-0 fish, and with parasite levels decreasing
   with age (age-1 snapper 40%; age-2 snapper 0%). The morphological,
   molecular and phylogenetic characterisation of the myxozoan showed that
   it is a member of the typically marine, polysporoplasmid Sphaerospora
   spp. which form a subclade within the Sphaerospora sensu stricto clade
   of myxozoans, which is characterised by large expansion segments in
   their SSU rDNA sequences. Presporogonic stages of S. motemarini n. sp.
   were detected in the blood, using PCR. Pseudoplasmodia and spores were
   found to develop in the renal corpuscles of the host, causing their
   massive expansion. Macroscopic and histopathological changes were
   observed in age-0 fish and show that S. motemarini n. sp. causes severe
   glomerulonephritis in L. griseus leading to a compromised host
   condition, which makes it more susceptible to stress (catch-and-release,
   predators, water quality) and can result in mortalities. These results
   are discussed in relation to the exploitation of grey snapper
   populations by commercial and recreational fisheries and with the
   observed increased mortalities with temperature along the coast of
   Florida. In the future, we would like to determine prevalence and
   intensity of infection with S. motemarini n. sp. in juvenile L. griseus
   in different areas of the Gulf of Mexico in order to be able to estimate
   the temperature dependence of S. motemarini n. sp. proliferation and to
   be able to predict its distribution and severity during climatic changes
   in the Gulf. (C) 2013 Australian Society for Parasitology Published by
   Elsevier Ltd. Open access under CC BY-NC-ND license.
C1 Holzer, Astrid S.; Acad Sci Czech Republ, Ctr Biol, Branisovska 31,
   Ceske Budejovice, CR-37005, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM astrid.holzer@paru.cas.cz
RI Holzer, Astrid Sibylle/E-2531-2011
OI Holzer, Astrid Sibylle/0000-0002-4916-3172; Main,
   Kevan/0000-0003-2104-1517
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 2213-2244
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Lutjanus griseus [Myxozoan parasites / Sphaerospora motemarini / New
   parasite species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Florida / New myxozoan parasite
   species]. 
   Sphaerospora motemarini [Piscean hosts / Lutjanus griseus / New parasite
   species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Florida / New species from piscean
   host]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates

   Perciformes, Lutjanidae, Myxozoa, Myxosporea, Bivalvulida
OR Lutjanus griseus (Lutjanidae): [Host]. 
   Sphaerospora motemarini (Bivalvulida): [Sp nov, USA, Florida (marine),
   Parasite of Lutjanus griseus (Pisces), p. 126; Parasite].

   clarillii, P. quandti and P. tydecksjuerging, are described and figured.

   described along with images from the Andaman islands. This is the third

TI Studies on natural enemies of insect pests of drumstick.
AU Math, Mahesh (dsw@uhsbagalkot.edu.in) 
   Kotikal, Y.K.
   Madalageri, M.B.
SO Journal of Biological Control
VL 27
IS 4
PS 336-339
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Study conducted at the University of Horticultural Sciences, Bagalkot,
   Karnataka brought to light six species of insects, a spider and couple
   of birds as natural enemies in drumstick ecosystem during the year
   2012-13. Out of the natural enemies recorded, six were predators and one
   was parasitoid on pests in drumstick. The lady bird beetle, Cheilomenes
   sexmaculata Fabricius, pentatomid bug, Eocanthecona furcellata (Wolf),
   green lace wing, Chrysoperla zastrowii sillemi (Esben-Peterson),
   gitonid, Cacoxenus sp., preying mantid, Anaxarcha limbata Goglio-Toss,
   an undetermined species of spider and a parasitoid, Agathis sp. were
   recorded.

   Erythraeidae) on zoophytophagous mirid bug, Nesidiocoris tenuis Reuter
   (Heteroptera: Miridae) is reported at fourth (tetra-) trophic level in
   the food chain comprising of tomato crop (first trophic level), insect

   (second trophic level), predatory mirid bug, N. tenuis (third-trophic
   level).

   genus Nomia Latreille (Hymenoptera; Apoidea; Halictidae) from Rajasthan,
   India.
AU Gupta, Rajiv K.
   Saini, Jagdish (beesind@gmail.com)

VL 27
IS 2
PS 253-256
PD December 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nomia (Nomia) singhi a new species of genus Nomia latreille
   (Hymenoptera, Apoidea, Halictidae), collected from various locations in
   Rajasthan, India has been described. The description of new species
   follows its comparison with closely related Nomia (Nomia) curvipes Fabr.
   also known from many locations in India and neighbouring countries. The
   data of new species and of N. curvipes is supported with their
   geographical distribution and flower records.

PT J
AN ZOOR15011059154
PM 24516270
DT Article
TI Morphological and Molecular Characterization of Lymnaeid Snails and
   Their Potential Role in Transmission of Fasciola spp. in Vietnam.
AU Bui Thi Dung (dung_parasitologist@yahoo.com) 
   Pham Ngoc Doanh
   Dang Tat The
   Ho Thi Loan
   Losson, Bertrand
   Caron, Yannick
SO Korean Journal of Parasitology
VL 51
IS 6
PS 657-662
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB Freshwater snails of the family Lymnaeidae play an important role in the
   transmission of fascioliasis worldwide. In Vietnam, 2 common lymnaeid
   species, Lymnaea swinhoei and Lymnaea viridis, can be recognized on the
   basis of morphology, and a third species, Lymnaea sp., is known to
   exist. Recent studies have raised controversy about their role in
   transmission of Fasciola spp. because of confusion in identification of
   the snail hosts. The aim of this study is, therefore, to clarify the
   identities of lymnaeid snails in Vietnam by a combination of
   morphological and molecular approaches. The molecular analyses using the
   second internal transcribed spacer (ITS2) of the nuclear ribosomal DNA
   clearly showed that lymnaeids in Vietnam include 3 species, Austropeplea
   viridis (morphologically identified as L. viridis), Radix auricularia
   (morphologically identified as L. swinhoei) and Radix rubiginosa
   (morphologically identified as Lymnaea sp.). R. rubiginosa is a new
   record for Vietnam. Among them, only A. viridis was found to be infected
   with Fasciola spp. These results provide a new insight into lymnaeid
   snails in Vietnam. Identification of lymnaeid snails in Vietnam and
   their role in the liver fluke transmission should be further
   investigated.
C1 Bui Thi Dung; Vietnam Acad Sci & Technol, Inst Ecol & Biol Resources, 18
   Hoang Quoc Viet, Hanoi, Vietnam, Vietnam.
EM dung_parasitologist@yahoo.com
OI Pham, Doanh/0000-0003-4995-3446; Caron, Yannick/0000-0003-3344-7311
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology;
   Parasitology
SN 0023-4001
BD Techniques; Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Genetics;
   Evolution; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth
   parasites; Hosts; Transmission; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia;
   Asia

   Fasciola / ] [Transmission of parasites / Fasciola (Platyhelminthes) / ]
   [Vietnam /  / ]. 
   Fasciola [Molluscan hosts / Austropeplea viridis / Prevalence] [ / Radix
   auricularia / ] [ / Radix rubiginosa / morphological & molecular
   characterization; transmission] [Transmission of parasites /
   Austropeplea viridis (Mollusca) / ] [ / Radix auricularia (Mollusca) / ]
   [ / Radix rubiginosa (Mollusca) / ] [Vietnam /  / ].

   transmission] [Shell morphology /  / ] [Molecular genetics / ITS-2 rDNA

   [Transmission of parasites / Fasciola (Platyhelminthes) / ] [Vietnam /

DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of the genus Nemophas Thomson, 1864 (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Vitali, Francesco
SO Lambillionea
VL 113
IS 3
PS 255-266
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nemophas Thomson, 1864, Iothocera Thomson, 1864 and Dolichoprosopus
   Ritsema, 1881 are compared and revised with emphasis on the genital
   morphology. Nemophas is recognised as a older synonym of Iothocera n.
   syn. Consequently, Apriona tomentosa Bouquet, 1859 is transferred to the
   genus Nemophas as follows : Nemophas tomentosus (Bouquet, 1859) n. comb.
   Dolichoprosopus incensus Pascoe, 1866 and Dolichoprosopus leuciscus
   Pascoe, 1866 are restored within Nemophas as follows : Nemophas incensus
   Pascoe, 1866 rest. comb. Nemophas leuciscus Pascoe, 1866 rest. comb.
   Nemophas subcylindricus Aurivillius, 1927 is transferred to
   Dolichoprosopus as follows : Dolichoprosopus subcylindricus
   (Aurivillius, 1927) n. comb. Nemophas sumbaensis n. sp. from Sumba
   (Lesser Sunda) and Nemophas nigriceps n. sp. from Sulawesi are
   described. A new key to the genus Nemophas is proposed..
C1 Vitali, Francesco; 7a Rue Jean Pierre Huberty, Luxembourg, L-1742,
   Luxembourg, Luxembourg.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0774-2819

   Taxonomic position; Key; General morphology; Reproduction; Reproductive
   system; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   implications] [Genitalia / Genital morphology / ]. 
   Nemophas nigriceps; Nemophas sumbaensis [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Cerambycidae

   p. 259].

   Nemophas, p. 258].

   Nemophas, p. 258]. 
   Dolichoprosopus subcylindricus - (Aurivillius 1927) (Cerambycidae):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Nemophas, p. 258]. 
   Iothocera - Thomson 1864 (Cerambycidae).

   1864, p. 259; Key to species, P. 262].

   Dolichoprosopus, p. 258].

PT J
AN ZOOR15112081198
DT Article
TI Estimated bycatch of marine mammals and sea turtles in the U.S. Atlantic
   pelagc longline fleet during 2012.
AU Garrison, Lance P.
   Stokes, Lesley
SO NOAA Technical Memorandum NMFS-SEFSC
VL 655
PS i-iv, 1-56
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The U.S. Atlantic Pelagic Long line fleet operates throughout the
   northwestern Atlantic Ocean, including along the U.S. coast from the
   Gulf of Mexico to New England, the waters of the Caribbean, and in
   international waters of the North Atlantic Ocean. The Atlantic longline
   fleet is defined as a Category I fishery under the Marine Mammal
   Protection Act, and it is also the subject of management under the
   Endangered Species Act due to interactions with leatherback (Dermochelys
   coriacea) and loggerhead (Caretta caretta) turtles. Total bycatch of
   marine mammals and turtles in the longline fishery was estimated for
   2012 using data from the pelagic longline fishery observer prop-am and a
   mandatory fishery logbook reporting program. We applied a
   delta-lognormal approach to estimate region specific and total annual
   interactions with protected species in the fishery. During 2012, there
   were an estimated 596.2 (424.7-837.0 (95% CI)) interactions with
   leatherback turtles and 680.7 (518.0-894.5 (95% CI)) interactions with
   loggerhead turtles. The primary marine mammals interacting with this
   fishery were pilot whales (Globicephala sp.) with an estimated 242.6
   (145.8-404.0 (95% Cl)) interactions with unspecified pilot whales and an
   additional 10.0 (2.0-51.0 (95% CI)) interactions with genetically
   identified short-finned pilot whales. Potential sources of bias and
   uncertainty in these bycatch estimates are discussed.
C1 Garrison, Lance P.; Natl Marine Fisheries Serv, SE Fisheries Sci Ctr, 75
   Virginia Beach Dr, Miami, FL 33149, USA, USA.
SC Zoology; Fisheries
BD Animals and man; Disturbance by man; Commercial activities; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Chelonioidea; Mammalia [Fishing and fisheries / Pelagic longline fishery
   / Bycatch estimation] [North Atlantic / USA / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Cryptodira
OR Mammalia (Vertebrata). 
   Chelonioidea (Cryptodira). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15112081198
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15008037361
DT Article
TI Late Albian Scleractinian corals from the Prebetic Zone (SE Spain).
AU Loeser, Hannes (loeser@paleotax.de) 
   Manuel Castro, Jose
   Nieto, Luis M.
SO Palaeontographica Abteilung A Palaeozoologie-Stratigraphie
VL 301
IS 1-2
PS 1-61
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB From the Prebetic Zone (South-East Spain) the first Late Albian western
   Tethys shallow marine coral fauna is described. It encompasses 35
   species in 28 genera of the suborders Amphiastraeina, Faviina,
   Heterocoeniina, Microsoleniina, Poritina, Rhipidogyrina, and Stylinina
   including two new genera (suborder Heterocoeniina) and six new species.
   The family Elasmocoeniidae DUNCAN, 1884, within the suborder
   Heterocoeniina is reintroduced. It encompasses all genera with a
   bilateral septal symmetry formerly assigned to the Heteroeniidae family.
   Two genera of this family - Pleurodendron and Heteropistophyllum - are
   described as new. The type species of Pleurodendron, Pleurodendron
   prebeticum, is new, whereas Heteropistophyllum is based on
   Pseudopistophyllum quinqueseptatum Turnsek & Buser, 1976. Both genera
   are known from other localities older than the study area. The fauna
   contains the last indication of the Amphiastreid genera Aulastrea,
   Metaulastrea and Mitrodendron, whose last occurrence was previously
   known as being Aptian. This finding extends the range of the
   Amphiastraeina suborder until the Late Albian. The fauna encompasses
   more species that are known from the Aptian and Early Albian than
   species that have been previously found in the Cenomanian. Also the
   generic composition of the fauna is similar to Early Cretaceous faunas.
   For the Late Cretaceous and Tertiary genus Actinacis the study area
   represents the first occurrence, including the first ever occurrence of
   the suborder Poritina.
C1 Loeser, Hannes; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Geol, Apartado Postal
   1039, Hermosillo, Sonora, 83000, Mexico, Mexico.
EM loeser@paleotax.de
RI Nieto-Albert, Luis/K-6825-2014; Castro, Jose Manuel/L-7325-2014
OI Nieto-Albert, Luis/0000-0002-9907-2455; Castro, Jose
   Manuel/0000-0001-7710-9600
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0375-0442
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Mesozoic
DE Actinacis; Poritina [Spain /  / new record] [Tertiary /  / ] [Cretaceous
   / Late Cretaceous / ]. 
   Aulastraea crassicalix; Metaulastraea elae; Mitrodendron ultimus;
   Paraacanthogyra hispanica; Pleurodendron prebeticum; Silingastraea
   valentina [Spain /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Heteropistophyllum; Pleurodendron [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Scleractinia [Evolution /  / systematics] [Zoogeography /
   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Spain / South east / stratigraphical
   distribution] [Cretaceous / Late Albian / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Scleractinia
OR Scleractinia (Zoantharia): [Fossil]. 
   Actinacis (Scleractinia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Aulastraea crassicalix (Scleractinia): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P.
   10; Fossil]. 
   Elasmocoeniidae - Duncan 1884 (Scleractinia): [Status, P. 17; Taxonomic
   position, P. 17]. 
   Heteropistophyllum (Scleractinia): [Gen nov, Of family Elasmocoeniidae,
   Type species Pseudopistophyllum quinqueseptatum Turnsek & Buser 1976, p.
   18, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Heteropistophyllum quinqueseptatum - (Turnsek & Buser 1976)
   (Scleractinia): [Comb nov, Transferred from Pseudopistophyllum, p. 19]. 
   Metaulastraea elae (Scleractinia): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P. 11;
   Fossil]. 
   Mitrodendron ultimus (Scleractinia): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P. 11;
   Fossil]. 
   Paraacanthogyra hispanica (Scleractinia): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P.
   28; Fossil]. 
   Pleurodendron (Scleractinia): [Gen nov, Of family Elasmocoeniidae, Type
   species Pleurodendron prebeticum, p. 19, Cretaceous; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15403017429
DT Article
TI Cranial morphology and taxonomy of South African Tapinocephalidae
   (Therapsida: Dinocephalia): the case of Avenantia and Riebeeckosaurus.
AU Guven, Saniye (guven.saniye@gmail.com) 
   Rubidge, Bruce S.
   Abdala, Fernando
SO Palaeontologia Africana
VL 48
PS 24-33
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tapinocephalid dinocephalians comprise a large component of Middle
   Permian herbivorous tetrapod biodiversity and are significantly abundant
   in the Karoo rocks of South Africa. In order to understand the effect of
   the alleged Middle Permian extinction in the terrestrial record of
   amniotes a clear understanding of the taxonomic diversity of this group
   is essential. The tapinocephalids Avenantia kruisvleiensis and
   Riebeeckosaurus longirostris have in the past been distinguished by a
   set of characters, including differences in the snout length which was
   previously interpreted as a key diagnostic character. Further
   preparation of the material attributed to these species shows that the
   purported distinguishing characters, such as snout length, low
   intertemporal crest, and surface thickening of the parietal represent
   postmortem deformation (including distortion and weathering) or can be
   interpreted as individual or ontogenetic variation. Accordingly A.
   kruisvleiensis is synonimized with R. longirostris.
C1 Guven, Saniye; Univ Witwatersrand, Evolutionary Studies Inst, Private
   Bag 3, Johannesburg, ZA-2050, South Africa, South Africa.
EM guven.saniye@gmail.com
OI Rubidge, Bruce/0000-0003-2477-1873
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0078-8554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy; Skeletal
   and supporting structures; Skeleton; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Avenantia kruisvleiensis; Riebeeckosaurus longirostris [Skull / Cranial
   morphology / Systematics] [South Africa / Karoo Basin / ] [Permian /
   Middle Permian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Synapsida, Therapsida
OR Avenantia kruisvleiensis - Boonstra 1952 (Therapsida): [Redescription,
   P. 28; Fossil]. 
   Riebeeckosaurus - Boonstra 1952 (Therapsida): [Emended diagnosis, P. 32;
   Syn nov, Avenantia Boonstra 1952, p. 32]. 
   Riebeeckosaurus longirostris - Boonstra 1952 (Therapsida):
   [Redescription, P. 25; Syn nov, Avenantia kruisvleiensis Boonstra 1952,
   p. 32; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15403017429
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15403017430
DT Article
TI Cretaceous faunas from Zululand and Natal, South Africa. Texasia cricki
   Spath, 1921 (Cephalopoda: Ammonoidea) an early Santonian marker fossil
   from the Mzamba Formation of the Eastern Cape Province.
AU Kennedy, William James
   Klinger, Herbert Christian
SO Palaeontologia Africana
VL 48
PS 34-40
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The type material of 'Gen. nov. (Muniericeras?)' cricki Spath, 1921,
   from the Santonian part of the Mzamba Formation, Eastern Cape Province,
   is revised, and referred to Texasia Reeside, 1932, of which Lehmaniceras
   Collignon, 1966 is a subjective junior synonym. Lehmaniceras sornayi, L.
   acutum, L. macer, L. pingue, L. ultimum and possibly L. gracile of
   Collignon, 1966, originally described from Madagascar, are further
   synonyms, as is Barroisiceras umzambiensis van Hoepen, 1968, which is
   based on a single specimen from Mzamba. The species occurs in the lower
   part of the Zone of Texanites hourcqi in Madagascar, confirmed here as
   lower, rather than middle, Santonian.
C1 Kennedy, William James; Univ Oxford, Museum Nat Hist, Parks Rd, Oxford,
   OX1 3PR, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
SC Zoology
SN 0078-8554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Texasia cricki [Madagascar /  / systematics] [South Africa / Eastern
   Cape / ] [Cretaceous / Santonian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Ammonitida
OR Lehmaniceras - Collignon 1966 (Ammonitida): [Junior synonym, Of Texasia
   Reeside 1932, p. 34]. 
   Lehmaniceras cricki - (Spath 1921) (Ammonitida): [Referred to, Texasia,
   p. 34]. 
   Texasia - Reeside 1932 (Ammonitida): [Senior synonym, Of Lehmaniceras
   Collignon 1966, p. 34]. 
   Texasia cricki - (Spath 1921) (Ammonitida): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Lehmaniceras, p. 34; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15103013597
DT Article
TI An Embryonic Enantiornithine Bird and Associated Eggs from the
   Cretaceous of Mongolia.
AU Kurochkin, E.N. (sankar.chatterjee@ttu.edu) 
   Chatterjee, S.
   Mikhailov, K.E.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 11
PS 1252-1269
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Enantiornithes is the most speciose clade of Cretaceous birds, but many
   taxa are known from isolated postcranial skeletons. Two embryonic
   enantiornithine bird skeletons of Gobipipus reshetovi gen. et sp. nov.
   from the Upper Cretaceous (Campanian) Barun Goyot Formation of the Gobi
   Desert in Mongolia provide new insights into the anatomy, radiation, and
   mode of development of early avialans. In recent times, both
   enantiornithine and ornithuromorph birds are known from the Barun Goyot
   Formation as well as from the Djadokhta and Nemegt Formations. The
   80-million-year-old Gobipipus skeletons encased within eggshells shows
   several features characteristic of enantiornithine birds. The wing
   skeleton and shoulder girdle show morphological features indicating that
   Gobipipus achieved sophisticated powered flight. Gobipipus reshetovi
   gen. et sp. nov. is quite distinct from the sympatric enantiornithine
   species Gobipteryx minuta from the same strata in many anatomical
   features. Phylogenetic analysis of 26 avialan ingroup taxa based on
   distribution of 202 characters indicate that Gobipipus is a basal member
   of enantiornithine birds along with Confuciusornis and shares more
   characters with ornithuromorphs than previously recognized. The
   embryonic nature of Gobipipus specimens sheds new light on the
   developmental history of enantiornithine birds. The well-ossified bones
   of the fore- and hind limbs, and fusion of many skeletal elements
   indicate a precocial mode of development in Gobipipus. Apparently
   Gobipipus hatchlings could walk away from the ground nests as soon as
   they emerged from their eggs. The asymmetry of egg poles are unique
   features of Gobipipus eggs (oogenus Gobioolithus) among Cretaceous
   avialans. The microstructure of the shell in Gobioolithus eggs with the
   embryos of Gobipipus is typical avian (of ornithoid basic type) and less
   ratite-like in morphology of the spongy layer than is that in the other
   possible egg-remains of enantiornitine birds (oofamily
   Laevisoolithidae).
C1 Kurochkin, E.N.; Russian Acad Sci, Borissiak Paleontol Inst, 123
   Profsojuznaya St,Moscow GSP 7, Moscow, 117868, Russia, Russia.
EM sankar.chatterjee@ttu.edu
RI Chatterjee, Sankar/A-3801-2016
OI Chatterjee, Sankar/0000-0002-1065-0782
SC Zoology
SN 0031-0301
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Gobipipus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Gobipipus reshetovi [Mongolia /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves
OR Gobipipus (Aves): [Gen nov, Of Enantiornithes, Type species Gobipipus
   reshetovi, p. 1253, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Gobipipus reshetovi (Aves): [Sp nov, Mongolia, Cretaceous, P. 1255;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103013597
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15103013599
DT Article
TI Another Charadriiform-Like Bird from the Lower Eocene of Denmark.
AU Bertelli, S. (sbertelli@lillo.org.ar) 
   Lindow, B.E.K.
   Dyke, G.J.
   Mayr, G.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 11
PS 1282-1301
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 5
AB We describe an exceptionally well-preserved partial skeleton of a new
   bird from the early Eocene Fur Formation of Denmark. Like other fossils
   from these marine deposits, the partial skeleton is three-dimensionally
   preserved and articulated. This new Danish specimen consists of a skull,
   vertebral column, ribs, pelvis, and hindlimbs. Concerning characters of
   the pelvis, tibiotarsus and tarsometatarsus, the new fossil bears
   morphological affinities to charadriiform birds (shorebirds and
   relatives). A phylogenetic analysis of higher neomithine (modern birds)
   taxa also supports a close relationship between the new specimen and
   modern Charadriiformes. The morphologies of the skull and vertebrae,
   however, distinguish the new fossil from all recent charadriiform
   families.
C1 Bertelli, S.; Fdn Miguel Lillo CONICET, Miguel Lillo 251, San Miguel De
   Tucuman, Tucuman, RA-4000, Argentina, Argentina.
EM sbertelli@lillo.org.ar
RI Dyke, Gareth/AAJ-9320-2020
OI Dyke, Gareth/0000-0002-8390-7817

   Scandiavis mikkelseni [Denmark /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ].

DT Article
TI Cenozoic phoenicopteriform birds from central Asia.
AU Zelenkov, N.V. (nzelen@paleo.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 11
PS 1323-1330
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new phoenicopteriform bird, Palaelodus kurochkini sp. nov., is
   described from the terminal middle Miocene of Mongolia (the Sharga
   locality) on the basis of a partial tibiotarsus and tentatively
   associated fragmentary tarsometatarsus, carpometacarpus and proximal
   phalanx of the major wing digit. This is the first record of the extinct
   phoenicopteriform family Palaelodidae in Asia and shows that the genus
   Palaelodus is one of few taxa in the Sharga fauna to have a wide
   distribution range. Two other fossils of Phoenicopteriform birds from
   the Cenozoic of Central Asia are also restudied in this work; Agnopterus
   turgaiensis from the early Oligocene of Kazakhstan is provisionally
   placed within the extant family Phoenicopteridae, and Cygnopterus
   lambrechti, also from the Lower Oligocene of Kazakhstan, is identified
   as belonging to an indeterminate phoenicopteriform family.
C1 Zelenkov, N.V.; RAS, Borissiak Paleontol Inst, Moscow, Russia, Russia.
EM nzelen@paleo.ru
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0031-0301
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Palaelodidae [Asia /  / new record; systematics] [Miocene / Middle
   Miocene / ]. 
   Palaelodus kurochkini [Mongolia /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Phoenicopteriformes [Asia / Central / taxonomic review] [Caenozoic /  /
   ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates

   Ciconiiformes, Phoenicopteridae

   Cygnopterus lambrechti - Kurochkin 1968 (Anatidae): [Taxonomic position,
   Phoenicopteriformes, family incertae sedis, p. 1327]. 
   Agnopterus - Milne-Edwards 1867 (Ciconiiformes): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   1326; Referred to, Phoenicopteridae, p. 1327]. 
   Palaelodidae - Stejneger 1885 (Ciconiiformes): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Palaelodus kurochkini (Phoenicopteridae): [Sp nov, Mongolia, Miocene, P.
   1324; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103013603
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15103013604
DT Article
TI A bittern (Aves: Ardeidae) from the early Miocene of New Zealand.
AU Worthy, T.H. (trevor.worthy@flinders.edu.au) 
   Worthy, J.P.
   Tennyson, A.J.D.
   Scofield, R.P.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 11
PS 1331-1343
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Herons (Aves: Ardeidae) are rare in the fossil record globally. Fossil
   taxa referred to Ardeinae and Nycticoracini are known from as early as
   the early Oligocene and ardeids undetermined to subfamily include some
   as old as the early Eocene. In Australasia, the pre-Pliocene record is
   restricted to one species from the early Miocene of New Zealand. On the
   basis of a tarsometatarsus and a coracoid we describe a new species of
   bittern (Ardeidae: Botaurinae) from the St Bathans Fauna, of early
   Miocene age, from Otago, New Zealand. This is only the third and the
   oldest pre-Quaternary record for Botaurinae globally.

PT J

DT Article
TI A new species of Late Pleistocene rail (Aves: Rallidae) from Abaco, the
   Bahamas.
AU Steadman, D.W. (dws@flmnh.ufl.edu) 
   Morris, J.R.
   Wright, N.A.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 11
PS 1355-1364
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe a new species of rail from the Sawmill Sink blue hole on
   Abaco Island in the northern Bahamas. Known from abundant, beautifully
   preserved Late Pleistocene fossils, Rallus cyanocavi sp. nov. was a
   medium-sized, flightless species that probably was endemic to the Little
   Bahama Bank, which is a carbonate platform surrounded by deeper water.
   We are uncertain whether R. cyanocavi survived into the Holocene, when
   higher sea levels transformed the Little Bahama Bank from a single
   large, Late Pleistocene island (ca. 12000 km2) to the scattering of
   smaller islands seen today, the largest of which is Abaco (1681 km2).
   Fossils of additional extinct, flightless species of Rallus probably
   await discovery on some of the 21 other carbonate banks that span the
   Bahamian Archipelago.
C1 Steadman, D.W.; Univ Florida, Florida Museum Nat Hist, Gainesville, FL,
   32611, USA, USA.
EM dws@flmnh.ufl.edu
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0031-0301
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; Central America; West Indies; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Rallus cyanocavi [Bahamas /  / new species] [Pleistocene /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Gruiformes, Rallidae

   taxa, P. 1360]. 
   Rallus cyanocavi (Rallidae): [Sp nov, Bahamas, Pleistocene, P. 1358;
   Fossil].

PT J

DT Article
TI Palaecysta gen. nov., the greatest Systematophora imposter no more:
   introducing a lineage of latest Jurassic to Early Cretaceous
   (Tithonian-Hauterivian) dinoflagellate cysts from Madagascar.
AU Chen, Yow-Yuh (yowyuh.chen@exxonmobil.com) 
SO Palynology
VL 37
IS 2
PS 259-297
PD Dec 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A lineage of dinoflagellate cysts possessing arcuate process clusters
   from Madagascar is described. The lineage has helped to reveal the true
   identity of a group of skolochorate dinoflagellate cysts, bearing
   numerous long processes and process clusters, which have been reported
   as species of Systematophora. The revelation is that that group does not
   belong to Systematophora, but affiliates with the Madagascar lineage. A
   new genus, Palaecysta, is proposed. Seven new species: P. integra (type
   species), P. crispabaculata, P. foveoreticulata, P. melakyensis, P.
   morondavaensis, P. pectita, and P. virgae; eight new subspecies: P.
   integra subsp. digitata, P. integra subsp. mahajangaensis, P.
   crispabaculata subsp. delicata, P. foveoreticulata subsp.
   madagascarensis, P. palmula subsp. ankamotraensis, P. pectita subsp.
   merinai, P. virgae subsp. externa, and P. virgae subsp. lanceolata; and
   three new combinations: P. complicata (Neale and Sarjeant, 1962), P.
   palmula (Davey, 1982), and P. silyba (Davey, 1979a) are described.
   Palaecysta shares some morphological features with Systematophora,
   including skolochorate cyst, intra- to penitabular paratabulation, and
   gonyaulacacean, sexiform and apical archeopyle, but differs in having
   arcuate process clusters and two unlinked isolated paracingular
   processes in each paracingular paraplate, as oppose to nearly
   penitabular, annulate process clusters and two linked (by a low basal
   ridge) paracingular processes in each paracingular paraplate in the
   latter genus. Palaecysta occurred globally from the Tithonian to the
   Hauterivian. Its rapid evolution provides useful timelines for
   biostratigraphy; six assemblage zones are established. The zonation is
   compared with that from neighbouring regions in Australia and Papua New
   Guinea. The morphological differences and similarities between
   Palaecysta and other related genera, Systematophora, Kilwacysta, and
   Amphorulacysta gen. nov., are discussed. The significance of the arcuate
   dinoflagellate cysts group and the interrelationship amongst their
   member genera, reflected in the geological record, are commented upon.
   The genus Amphorula is emended.
C1 Chen, Yow-Yuh; ExxonMobil Explorat Co, 233 Benmar Dr, Houston, TX,
   77060, USA, USA.
EM yowyuh.chen@exxonmobil.com
SC Zoology
SN 0191-6122
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Available name;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   pectita; Palaecysta virgae [Madagascar /  / new species] [Cretaceous / 
   / ].

DT Article
TI Graptodinium, a new Paleogene dinoflagellate cyst.
AU Clowes, Christopher D. (chris@peripatus.gen.nz) 
SO Palynology
VL 37
IS 2
PS 316-324
PD Dec 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Graptodinium is a new genus of proximate dinoflagellate cysts with an
   apical archaeopyle, a cladopyxiacean tabulation and a distinctive
   intratabular ornamentation. It is represented by Graptodinium inconditum
   sp. nov. and Graptodinium omnireticulatum sp. nov. These species range
   from the Middle Eocene to at least the Early Oligocene in New Zealand.
   Graptodinium ranges geographically from the Arctic to the high southerly
   latitudes.

   600, Wellington, New Zealand, New Zealand.

DT Article
TI Biology of Kalipharynx sp (Trematoda: Digenea) metacercariae in
   Biomphalaria (Gasteropoda: Planorbidae) from Northeastern Argentina.
AU Virginia Fernandez, Maria (mvirginiafernandez@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Ines Hamann, Monika
   Ignacio Kehr, Arturo
SO Revista de Biologia Tropical
VL 61
IS 4
PS 1647-1656
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In Argentina, no ecological studies have been reported on the infection
   parameters of Kalipharynx sp. metacercariae in planorbid snails. To this
   end, the aims of this study were: (i) to provide information on the
   population biology of Kalipharynx sp. metacercariae in the planorbid
   snails Biomphalaria tenagophila and B. occidentalis through the study of
   prevalence and intensity of larval infection during a seasonal cycle;
   (ii) to evaluate the effects of host shell size on prevalence and
   infection intensity, (iii) to evaluate the effect of infection intensity
   on cyst size. Samples were taken between June 2010 and April 2011
   (encompassing all seasons) from a subtropical permanent pond in
   Corrientes City, Corrientes, Argentina. A total of 362 metacercariae
   (n=262 and n=100; from B. tenagophila and B. occidentalis respectively)
   were collected from 616 snails (n=466 and n=150 from B. tenagophila and
   B. occidentalis respectively). The metacercarial cysts were found in the
   digestive gland, mantle cavity, intestine and ovotestis. B. tenagophila
   showed a range of infection from 1 to 60 cysts per snail (mean=4.5[plus
   or minus]SD=9:9), and cyst diameter ranging between 255 and 705[mu]m
   (466.4[plus or minus]119); while, B. occidentalis showed a range of
   infection from 1 to 23 (5.5[plus or minus]5.6), and cyst diameter
   ranging between 310 to 900[mu]m (554.5[plus or minus]150). Results
   obtained indicated that, although absent in autumn, metacercariae of
   Kalipharynx sp. were present most of the year in both species of
   Biomphalaria, showing high values in both warm-season. Furthermore, both
   the infection intensity and host shell size varied significantly between
   seasons, although no seasonal variation was observed with respect to
   metacercarial cyst size, suggesting the possibility of more than one
   peak of cercariae emergence during the year. The prevalence of infection
   was significantly and positively correlated with snail size in both host
   species (p<0.05). The smallest host size class harbouring a
   metacercarial infection was 7.1-8.0mm and 11.1-12.0mm in B. tenagophila
   and B. occidentalis, respectively. The mean intensity of infection was
   positively correlated with snail size, but this relation was significant
   only in B. tenagophila (p<0.05). However, non-significant negative
   correlations were observed for intensity of infection vs cyst size in
   both host species (p>0.05). The results of this study show a significant
   influence of host size on prevalence and infection intensity, and a
   tendency towards density-dependent reductions in the growth of cysts.
   This is the first study in Argentina analyzing the population biology of
   Kalipharynx sp. metacercariae.
C1 Virginia Fernandez, Maria; CONICET, CECOAL, Ruta Prov 5Km 2-5,W 3400
   AMD, Corrientes, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mvirginiafernandez@yahoo.com.ar
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology; Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences
SN 0034-7744
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Shell morphology; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Abiotic
   factors; Physical factors; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Biomphalaria occidentalis; Biomphalaria tenagophila [Shell biometrics /
   Shell size / prevalence; biology] [Digenean parasites / Kalipharynx / ]
   [Climate and weather / Precipitation / ] [Temperature /  / ] [Argentina
   / Corrientes, Corrientes city / ]. 
   Kalipharynx [Molluscan hosts / Biomphalaria occidentalis / Prevalence;
   metacercariae] [ / Biomphalaria tenagophila / ] [Climate and weather /
   Precipitation / ] [Temperature /  / ] [Argentina / Corrientes,
   Corrientes city / biology]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Basommatophora, Planorboidea,
   Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea

   Biomphalaria tenagophila (Planorboidea): [Host]. 
   Kalipharynx (Digenea): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI A review of the genus Pseudobironium Pic (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
   Scaphidiinae).
AU Loebl, Ivan (ivan.lobl@bluewin.ch) 
   Tang, Liang
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 120
IS 4
PS 665-734
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB At present, 41 species of Pseudobironium Pic are recognized as valid,
   the following are described as new: P. antennatum sp. nov., P. augur sp.
   nov., P. bilobum sp. nov., P brancuccii sp. nov., P. confusum sp. nov.,
   P. conspectum sp. nov., P. convexum sp. nov., P flagellatum sp. nov., P.
   fujianum sp. nov., P. horaki sp. nov., P. incisum sp. nov., javanum sp.
   nov., P. merkli sp. nov., P. montanum sp. nov., P. parabicolor sp. nov.,
   P. pseudobicolor sp. nov., P. pubiventer sp. nov., P schuhi sp. nov., P.
   spinipes sp. nov., and P stewarti sp. nov. Pseudobironium tonkineum Pic
   is synonymized with P. languei (Achard), P. castaneurn Pic is
   synonymized with P. carinense (Achard), and P. dohertyi (Achard) is
   synonymized with P. vitalisi (Achard). Lectotypes are designated for P.
   achardi (Pic), P. carinense (Achard), P. dohertyi (Achard), P. feai Pic,
   P. subovatum Pic, P. tonkineum Pic, and P. vitalisi (Achard).
   Redescriptions or additional diagnostic characters and illustrations are
   given for P achardi (Pic), P. bicolor UN, P. carinense (Achard), P. feai
   Pic, P. grossum (Achard), P. languei (Achard), P. lewisi Achard, P.
   rufitarse Lobl, P sinicum Pic, P. sparsepunctatum (Pic), P. subovatum
   Pic, P. ussuricum Lobl, and P. vitalisi (Achard). Four species groups
   are recognized, based on male genital characters. A key to species is
   provided. New distributional records are given for most of the
   previously described species.

OR Amalocera achardi - Pic 1920 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype designated, P.

   Morphoscapha carinense - Achard 1920 (Staphylinidae): [Lectotype

DT Article
TI Acarnidae (Porifera: Demospongiae: Poecilosclerida) from the Mexican
   Pacific Ocean with the description of six new species.
AU Maria Aguilar-Camacho, Jose (jmaguilarcam@gmail.com) 
   Luis Carballo, Jose
   Antonio Cruz-Barraza, Jose
SO Scientia Marina
VL 77
IS 4
PS 677-696
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The family Acarnidae is characterized by sponges with ectosomal
   diactinal spicules and choanosomal monactinal spicules. Microscleres
   include palmate isochelae, toxas and echinating acanthostyles. We
   described ten species from the Mexican Pacific Ocean. Six of them are
   new to science: Acarnus michoacanensis n. sp., Acarnus oaxaquensis n.
   sp., Acarnus sabulum n. sp., Acheliderma fulvum n. sp., Megaciella
   toxispinosa n. sp. and Iophon bipocillum n. sp. Four are known in
   Eastern Pacific waters: Acarnus erithacus, Acarnus peruanus, Megaciella
   microtoxa and Iophon indentatum.

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC ASSESSMENT OF THE SUBSPECIFIC STATUS OF PHRYNOSOMA ORBICULARE
   (SAURIA: PHRYNOSOMATIDAE) IN THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF ITS DISTRIBUTION.
AU Barajas, Ruth Moreno
   Rodriguez-Romero, Felipe (fjrr@uaemex.mx) 
   Velazquez Rodriguez, Alma S.
   Mendez de la Cruz, Fausto R.
SO Southwestern Naturalist
VL 58
IS 4
PS 459-464
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Phrynosoma orbiculare is an endemic species of lizards in Mexico and is
   distributed from the northern part of the country to the central
   highlands. This species is found in open areas among scrubs, grasses,
   yuccas, and herbaceous plants. In our study, we performed two
   multivariate analyses (principal components and discriminant functions)
   to examine morphological and geographic variation among populations of
   P. orbiculare at the edge of the southern distribution of the species.
   Our assessment was to determine the taxonomic status of the subspecies
   Phrynosoma orbiculare orbiculare, P. o. cortezii, and P. o. boucardi
   described for this geographic zone. The analyses employed 10 informative
   diagnostic traits from digitalized images. Our results confirm only two
   subspecies, P. o. orbiculare and P. o. cortezii, in the study area. In
   addition, two new localities for the distribution of the species have
   been included (Nopalillo, Hidalgo, and Amealco, Queretaro). Moreover,
   the morphometrics of the organisms from new localities revealed that all
   individuals were positioned in the P. o. cortezii group and that the
   distribution of this subspecies extends west of the original records. We
   propose that the two populations reported as P. o. boucardi can be
   renamed as P. o. cortezii.
C1 Rodriguez-Romero, Felipe; Univ Autonoma Estado Mexico, Lab Sistemas
   Biosustentables, Campus Univ El Cerrillo,Km 15-5, Toluca, 50200, Mexico,
   Mexico.
EM fjrr@uaemex.mx
RI , feloo/Z-1125-2019; Mendez, Fausto R./O-3512-2018
OI Mendez, Fausto R./0000-0002-5084-1276; Rodriguez Romero, Felipe de
   Jesus/0000-0003-4289-4623
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0038-4909
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Evolution; Variation; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America
DE Phrynosoma orbiculare [Morphological variation /  / Systematics] [Mexico
   /  / distribution]. 
   Phrynosoma orbiculare cortezii [Mexico / Hidalgo, Nopalillo & Queretaro,
   Amealco / New record]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Phrynosoma orbiculare (Iguanidae). 
   Phrynosoma orbiculare cortezii - Dumeril & Bocourt 1870 (Iguanidae):
   [Syn nov, Phrynosoma orbiculare boucardi Dumeril & Bocourt 1870, p. 464;
   New record].

DT Article
TI First Report of Polyplax sp. in a Persian Squirrel (Scuirus anomalus) in
   Tabriz, Northwest of Iran.
AU Shirazi, Shahrokh (sh.shirazi@srbiau.ac.ir) 
   Bahadori, Farhad
   Mostafaei, Tayebeh-Sadat
   Ronaghi, Hooman
SO Turkiye Parazitoloji Dergisi
VL 37
IS 4
PS 299-301
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Persian squirrel (Scuirus anomalus) has a long furry tail, which is
   longer than half of the body, and lives in the Zagros forest. It is
   distributed in the west and northeast of Asia. In the summer 2011 a
   Persian squirrel with signs of hair loss and itch in head and tail was
   referred to the veterinary clinic. There were arthropods in the lesion
   in the first survey. Many of these parasites were collected and were
   sent to Parasitology Laboratory of Science and Research University in
   Tehran. Samples were processed and were identified according to lices
   diagnostic keys using a light microscope. Lice that were sent to the
   national parasitology museum were identified as Polyplax sp. too.
C1 Shirazi, Shahrokh; Islamic Azad Univ, Div Sci & Res, Tehran, Iran, Iran.
EM sh.shirazi@srbiau.ac.ir

SN 1300-6320

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   [Iran / Tabriz / ]. 
   Sciurus anomalus [Anopluran parasites / Polyplax / ] [Iran / Tabriz / ].
   
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Insects; Invertebrates; Mammals; Rodents;

   Rodentia, Sciuridae
OR Polyplax (Anoplura): [Parasite; New record].

TI MINING FLIES OF THE GENUS OPHIOMYIA (DIPTERA, AGROMYZIDAE) OF EASTERN

VL 47
IS 6
PS E9-E31
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB During 2009-2013, twenty-three species of agromyzid flies from the genus
   Ophiomyia Braschnikov, 1897 were collected in the territory of eastern
   and south-eastern Ukraine. Among them, six species are described as new
   for science: Ophiomyia australis sp. n., O. crispa sp. n., O.
   fasciculusalba sp. n., O. malalata sp. n., O. punctata sp. n. and O.
   versera sp. n. Male heads and genitalia are illustrated for all species.
   Pictures of the female genitalia are also provided for I. curvipalpis
   (Zetterstedt, 1848), O. disordens Pakalniskis, 1998, I. fennoniensis
   Spencer, 1976, I. maura (Meigen, 1832), I. melandricaulis Hering, 1943,
   I. ranunculicaulis Hering, 1949, I. slovaca Cerny, 1994, I. skanensis
   Spencer, 1976 and I. submaura Hering, 1926. Information on distribution
   and host plants are also provided.

DT Article
TI REVELIERIA GROEHNI - A NEW SPECIES OF MINUTE BROWN SCAVENGER BEETLES
   (COLEOPTERA, LATRIDIIDAE) FROM BALTIC AMBER.
AU Sergi, T.A. (tatyana.sergi@mail.ru) 
   Perkovsky, E.E.
   Reike, H.-P.
SO Vestnik Zoologii
VL 47
IS 6
PS E43-E48
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Based on a fossil specimen from Late Eocene Baltic amber, Revelieria
   groehni Sergi, Perkovsky et Reike, sp. n., a new species is described.
   It is the first fossil species of the genus Revelieria Perris, 1869. The
   new species clearly differs from extant R. californica and R. genei in
   the following characters: eyes more large and convex; antennal insertion
   located more close to eye; temples very short; metasternum longer; fore
   tibia evenly curved inwards.
C1 Sergi, T.A.; Lambrova Str 16, Mykolaivka Dist, Odesa Region, UA-67050,
   Ukraine, Ukraine.

   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

PM 24415701
DT Article
TI Rearrangement of mitochondrial genome in fishes.
AU Gong, Li
   Shi, Wei
   Si, Li-Zhen
   Kong, Xiao-Yu (xykong@scsio.ac.cn) 
SO Zoological Research
VL 34
IS 6
PS 666-673
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Generally, the mitochondrial genome is characterized by the property of
   highly conserved organization. After comparing the 1,255 fish complete
   mitogenome sequences deposited in GenBank (as of Nov. 3, 2013),
   approximately 52 complete mitogenomes are found to have been rearranged.
   Of these species, three types of rearrangement[long dash]shuffling,
   translocation, and inversion[long dash]have been found. Further analysis
   shows that the sites of the rearrangements occur frequently in WANCY
   cluster, IQM cluster, ND6 gene, control region (D-loop) and its adjacent
   genes. Based on the four models that explain the gene rearrangements
   commonly adopted by scientists, we attempted to infer the possible
   mechanisms for the three types of gene rearrangement as well as the
   application of gene rearrangement in phylogenetic studies.
C1 Kong, Xiao-Yu; Key Laboratory of Marine Bio-resources Sustainable
   Utilization, South China Sea Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of
   Sciences, Guangzhou, 510301, China, China.
EM xykong@scsio.ac.cn
SC Zoology; Cell Biology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0254-5853
BD Cytology; Protoplasm; Organelles; Genetics
DE Pisces [Mitochondria / Mitochondrial genome / Rearrangement] [Molecular
   genetics /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Pisces (Vertebrata). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15101001755
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15102006255
DT Article
TI A new species of oribatid mites of the genus Protoribates (Acari,
   Oribatida, Haplozetidae) from Ethiopia.
AU Ermilov, S.G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Rybalov, L.B.
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 92
IS 12
PS 1478-1481
PD Dec 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new oribatid mite species, Protoribates aethiopicus sp. n., from
   Ethiopia is described. This species is morphologically similar to Proton
   bates dentatus (Berlese 1883), but differs from it in the longer
   lamellae and notogastral setae, shorter adanal setae ad1 and smaller
   notogastral porose areas, as well as in the presence of two claws on all
   the leg pairs.
C1 Ermilov, S.G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, 625003, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI First occurrence of Perkinsyllis San Martin, Lopez & Aguado, 2009
   (Polychaeta: Syllidae) in Brazil, with descriptions of two new species.
AU Fukuda, Marcelo Veronesi (mvfukuda@gmail.com) 
   De Matos Nogueira, Joao Miguel
SO Marine Biology Research
VL 9
IS 10
PS 972-989
PD Dec 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 23
AB Perkinsyllis is recorded for the first time in Brazilian waters with
   three species, two of which are new to science. Perkinsyllis longisetosa
   has unidentate dorsal simple chaetae, with coarse spinulation; bidentate
   blades of falcigers, with a rounded distal tooth and coarse spines; and
   spiniger-like dorsal-most compound chaetae. Perkinsyllis koolalyoides
   sp. nov. has dorsal simple chaetae unidentate on anterior-most
   chaetigers, bidentate to distally bifid on remaining chaetigers, with
   distal-most spine reaching beyond level of subdistal tooth; compound
   chaetae as falcigers with bidentate blades with long spines, distal-most
   spines reaching beyond the level of the subdistal tooth; spiniger-like
   chaetae absent. Perkinsyllis biota sp. nov. has dorsal simple chaetae
   unidentate on anterior-most chaetigers and distally bifid, with short
   spinulation on remaining chaetigers; bidentate blades of falcigers with
   long spines, distal-most spines reaching beyond level of subdistal
   tooth; and 1-5 spiniger-like dorsal-most compound chaetae, bidentate,
   with short spinulation. We present a key to all described species of
   Perkinsyllis, including an Australian species referred to this genus for
   the first time.
C1 Fukuda, Marcelo Veronesi; Univ Sao Paulo, Dept Zool, R Matao,Trav
   14,101, Sao Paulo, BR-05508900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM mvfukuda@gmail.com
RI nogueira, Joao/K-4660-2016; Fukuda, Marcelo Veronesi/H-1736-2016
OI nogueira, Joao/0000-0002-8450-4294; Fukuda, Marcelo
   Veronesi/0000-0002-7849-5563
SC Zoology
SN 1745-1000
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Perkinsyllis biota; Perkinsyllis koolalyoides [South Atlantic / Brazil /
   New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Perkinsyllis - San Martin, Lopez & Aguado 2009 (Polychaeta): [Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, P. 978; Key to species, P. 973].

DT Article
TI New records and species of Enchelidiidae (Nematoda): Symplocostoma
   brasiliensis sp nov and a first description of the female of
   Calyptronema pigmentatum Gerlach, 1957.
AU Neres, Patricia Fernandes (patricia_neres@yahoo.om.br) 
   Fonseca-Genevois, Veronica G.
   Esteves, Andre Morgado
SO Marine Biology Research
VL 9
IS 10
PS 990-1004
PD Dec 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 35
AB This contribution presents a new species of Symplocostoma, the first
   member of this genus identified for the coast of Brazil, and a
   dichotomous key for species of the genus. There is also a redescription
   of the male and the first description of the female of Calyptronema
   pigmentatum. Samples were collected on the continental shelf of the
   Potiguar Basin, northeastern Brazil. Symplocostoma brasiliensis sp. nov.
   has several distinguishing characteristics: the position of the
   secretory-excretory pore, tail length, the presence of denticles in the
   buccal cavity (female) and the number of precloacal supplements (male).
   The male of C. pigmentatum showed most morphological and morphometric
   characters of the original description, except for the size of the
   amphidial fovea and the number of precloacal supplements. The male
   differs from C. maxweberi in the spicular apparatus, gubernaculum shape,
   number of precloacal papillae and tail length. The female of the species
   has a buccal cavity similar to that of C. mawsoni, but differs in the
   position of the secretory-excretory pore and the shape of the amphidial
   fovea and tail.
C1 Neres, Patricia Fernandes; Univ Fed Pernambuco, Dept Zool, Av Prof
   Moraes Rego S-N, Recife, PE, BR-50670901 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM patricia_neres@yahoo.om.br

DT Article
TI Penilidia desbarresi sp nov (Echinodermata: Holothuroidea: Elasipodida)
   from the upper slope of Newfoundland and re-description of P-ludwigi
   (von Marenzeller, 1893).
AU Gebruk, Andrey V. (agebruk@ocean.ru) 
   Rogacheva, Antonina V.
   Pawson, David L.
   Hamel, Jean-Francois
   Macisaac, Kevin G.
   Mercier, Annie
SO Marine Biology Research
VL 9
IS 10
PS 1029-1036
PD Dec 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 32
AB Penilpidia desbarresi sp. nov. was collected in the Desbarres Canyon at
   a depth of 525 m, off the southeastern coast of insular Newfoundland,
   eastern Canada. The new species differs from the type species Penilpidia
   ludwigi (von Marenzeller, 1983) in having larger middle spines on arched
   rod-type ossicles on the dorsum and by having the lobe around the
   posterior body end formed by six pairs of very small tube feet.
   Penilpidia desbarresi sp. nov was photographed in situ and sampled on a
   single occasion in July 2007. This gonochoric species
   ([approximately]1-2 cm long) was found on a muddy substrate and
   individuals were aggregated, reaching a density of [approximately]50
   ind. m-2. Preliminary evidence points to brooding, which would be a
   first for the family Elpidiidae. Penilpidia ludwigi, not recorded for
   more than 100 years after its first description, is re-described.
C1 Gebruk, Andrey V.; Russian Acad Sci, PP Shirshov Inst Oceanol,
   Nakhimovsky Pr 36, Moscow, 117997, Russia, Russia.
EM agebruk@ocean.ru
RI Kremenetskaia, Antonina/H-5654-2018; Mercier, Annie/B-4254-2012
OI Kremenetskaia, Antonina/0000-0001-8851-3318; Mercier,
   Annie/0000-0003-0807-2378
SC Zoology
SN 1745-1000
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; Canada
DE Penilpidia desbarresi [Newfoundland and Labrador /  / New species]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Holothuroidea
OR Penilpidia desbarresi (Holothuroidea): [Sp nov, Newfoundland and
   Labrador, P. 1032]. 
   Penilpidia ludwigi - (Von Marenzeller 1893) (Holothuroidea):
   [Redescription, P. 1031].

VL 19
IS 2
PS 199-206
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new anisolabidid earwig of the genus Anisolabis is described from
   Haha-jima and Ototo-jima, the Ogasawara Islands, Japan, with the
   illustration of salient features to distinguish it from the related
   species. This is possibly the first endemic species of the Dermaptera
   from the Ogasawara Islands.

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Tridactylophagus (Strepsiptera,
   Halictophagidae) from Kyoto, Japan.
AU Nakase, Yuta (yuta.nakase@gmail.com) 
   Kato, Makoto
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 19
IS 2
PS 227-230
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Tridactylophagus etoi sp. nov. is described from female specimens
   parasitic to tridactylidean pygmy mole crickets, Xya japonica
   (HAAN,1842) collected at Tango, Kyoto, Japan. It is the first record of
   Tridactylophagus from Japan. Morphologically the new species resembles T
   coniferus (YANG, 1964) occurring in China, but easily distinguished from
   T. coniferus by its shape of cephalothorax, position of spiracles and
   other morphological characters.
C1 Nakase, Yuta; Kyoto Univ, Grad Sch Human & Environm Studies, Kyoto,
   6068501, Japan, Japan.
EM yuta.nakase@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Entomology

   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Tridactylophagus etoi [Insect hosts / Xya japonica (Orthoptera) / New
   parasite species] [Japan /  / New species from insect host]. 
   Xya japonica [Strepsipteran parasites / Tridactylophagus etoi / New
   parasite species] [Japan /  / New strepsipteran parasite species].

U1 0
U2 0
AB Five omaliine species of the family Staphylinidae from the streamside of
   the Island of Sado off central Honshu of Japan are dealt with. One of
   them belonging to the genus Archaeoboreaphilus is described as being new
   to science under the name of A. sadoensis, and the remaining four
   species, Geodromicus caliginosus SHARP, G. sibiricus BERNHAUER,
   Phylidrodes dewanus Y. WATANABE and Boreaphilus japonicus (SHARP), are
   recorded as new to the fauna of this island.

DT Article
TI Arthropod Galls Found on Toshima and Shikinejima Islands, the Izu
   Islands, Japan.
AU Tokuda, Makoto
   Kawauchi, Kota
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 19
IS 2
PS 261-274
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB We surveyed arthropod galls on Toshima and Shikinejima Islands, the Izu
   Islands, Tokyo, Japan in November 2012 and May 2013 and found 31 sorts
   of gall, consisting of 20 cecidomyiid, four aphid, three psyllid, two
   eriophyoid, one tephritid, and one thrips galls. Twenty-eight and 14
   sorts of gall were newly recorded from Toshima and Shikinejima Islands,
   respectively. Among them, the following galls were new to the Izu
   Islands: leaf-vein gall induced by Trioza machilicola MIYATAKE
   (Hemiptera: Psylloidea) on Machilus thunbergii (Lauraceae), leaf gall
   induced by Tuberocephalus sakurae (MATSUMURA) (Hemiptera: Aphididae) on
   Prunus speciosa (Rosaceae), leaf gall induced by Eriophyes sp. (Acari:
   Eriophyidae) on Elaeocarpus sylvestris var. ellipticus (Elaeocarpaceae),
   leaf gall induced by Phyllocoptes sp. (Acari: Eriophyidae) on Stachyurus
   praecox var. matsuzakii (Stachyuraceae), flower bud gall induced by
   Asphondylia sp. (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) on Hedera rhombea (Araliaceae),
   leaf gall induced by Aphis clerodendri (MATSUMURA) (Hemiptera:
   Aphididae) on Clerodendrum trichotomum (Lamiaceae), bud gall induced by
   Rhopalomyia iwatensis SHINJI (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) on Artemisia
   indica var. maximowiczii (Asteraceae), and leaf gall induced by
   Cryptosiphum artemisiae BUCKTON (Hemiptera: Aphididae) on A. indica var.
   maximowiczii.
C1 Tokuda, Makoto; Saga Univ, Fac Agr, 1 Honjo, Saga, 8408502, Japan,
   Japan.

VL 19

PS 285-288

LA English
U1 0

AB The subfamily Scydmaeninae (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae) is recorded for
   the first time from Kumejima Island, the Ryukyus, Japan. A new species,
   Euconnus (Euconophron) kumejimensis sp. nov. is described. Cephennodes

   As a result of this study, the number of Japanese species of Euconnus
   becomes fifteen.

DT Article
TI A Taxonomic Study of the Genera Harmalia and Opiconsiva (Homoptera,
   Delphacidae) from Japan.
AU Fujintuma, Satoshi (leptodelphax@yahoo.ca.jp) 
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 19
IS 2
PS 335-350
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The delphacid planthopper genera Harmalia FENNAH and Opiconsiva DISTANT
   occurring in Japan are revised. Four species of Harmalia and two species
   of Opiconsiva are recognized from Japan. Opiconsiva anufrievi KWON, 1982
   and Harmalia gayasana (KWON, 1982) described from Korea are synonymous
   to H. sirokata (MATSUMURA et ISHIHARA, 1945); Harmalia aculeatus (YANG,
   1989) described from Taiwan is synonymous to H. heitensis (MATSUMURA et
   ISHIHARA, 1945); Opiconsiva sameshimai (MATSUMURA et ISHIHARA, 1945)
   described from Japan, O. koreacola (KWON, 1982) described from Korea,
   and Toya yanoi (ISHIHARA, 1952) described from Japan are synonymous to
   O. albicollis (MOTSCHULSKY, 1863); Opiconsiva nigra DING et TIAN, 1980
   described from China is synonymous to O. tangira (MATSUMURA, 1900).
   Three species of Harmalia and one species of Opiconsiva are newly
   recorded from Japan. Key to Japanese species on males is also given.
C1 Fujintuma, Satoshi; Asagaya Minami 1-20-20,Suginami Ku, Tokyo, 1660004,
   Japan, Japan.
EM leptodelphax@yahoo.ca.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Harmalia commelinae; Harmalia heitensis; Harmalia sirokata; Opiconsiva
   tangira [Japan /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Delphacidae
OR Harmalia - Fennah 1969 (Delphacidae): [Key to species, Japan, Males, p.
   349]. 
   Harmalia commelinae (Delphacidae): [New record]. 
   Harmalia heitensi - (Matsumura & Ishihara 1945) (Delphacidae): [Syn nov,
   Matutinus aculeatus Yang 1989, p. 340]. 
   Harmalia heitensis (Delphacidae): [New record]. 
   Harmalia sirokata - (Matsumura & Ishihara 1945) (Delphacidae): [Syn nov,
   Opiconsiva anufrievi Kwon 1982, p. 337; Syn nov, Opiconsiva gayasana
   Kwon 1982, p. 337; New record]. 
   Opiconsiva - Distant 1917 (Delphacidae): [Key to species, Japan, Males,
   p. 349]. 
   Opiconsiva albicollis - (Motschulsky 1863) (Delphacidae): [Syn nov,
   Corbulo koreacola Kwon 1982, p. 346; Syn nov, Kakuna sameshimai
   Matsumura & Ishihara 1945, p. 346; Syn nov, Sogata yanoi Ishihara 1952,
   p. 346].

DT Article
TI STYGOTHELPHUSA CRANBROOKI, A NEW SPECIES OF CAVE CRAB FROM GUA SIREH,
   SARAWAK, MALAYSIA (CRUSTACEA: DECAPODA: BRACHYURA: GECARCINUCIDAE).
AU Ng, Peter K.L. (dbsngkl@nus.edu.sg) 
SO Raffles Bulletin of Zoology
SU 29
PS 91-97
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of freshwater cave crab of the genus Stygothelphusa Ng,
   1989 (Gecarcinucidae) is described from Gua Sireh in Sarawak, Malaysia.
   The species is allied to S. bidiensis (Lanchester, 1900) and S. nobilii
   (Colosi, 1920) from other parts of Sarawak, but differs by its carapace
   physiognomy, pronounced epibranchial tooth, proportionately much longer
   ambulatory legs and distinctive male first gonopod structure.
C1 Ng, Peter K.L.; Natl Univ Singapore, Raffles Museum Biodivers Res, 14
   Sci Dr 4, Singapore, 117543, Singapore, Singapore.
EM dbsngkl@nus.edu.sg

SO Raffles Bulletin of Zoology
SU 29
PS 161-175
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Information on distribution, altitudinal range and taxonomy is provided
   on the shrews belonging to the family Soricidae that have been recorded
   from the Himalayan region. The geographical and historical knowledge of
   the study of mammals in the Himalayan region is briefly outlined and a
   formerly unrecognised species of Crocidura is described. Biogeographical
   patterns and species associations of the soricids of the Himalayan
   region are examined.

DT Article
TI A new species and new records for the subfamily Aleocharinae from
   Turkey.
AU Sert, Osman (sert@hacettepe.edu.tr) 
   Turan, Yavuz
   Firat, Senem
   Sabanoglu, Burcu
SO Journal of Insect Science (Tucson)
VL 13
PS Article140, 1-6
PD Nov 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study, a new Aleocharinae (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) species
   from Turkey, Gyrophaena cagatay sp. n. (Aksaray), is described and
   illustrated. In addition, new records are presented for seven species:
   Atheta hygrotopora (Kraatz, 1856), Atheta incognita (Sharp, 1869),
   Atheta ripicola Hanssen, 1932, Brachyusa concolor Erichson, 1839,
   Ischnopoda leucopus (Marsham, 1802), Ischnopoda subaenea Eppelsheim,
   1890, and Liogluta granigera Kiesenwetter, 1850. Photographs of the
   habitus of male and female specimens are presented. The 8th tergite and
   aedeagus of the male and the spermatheca of the female are also
   illustrated for the new species. Differential diagnosis guidelines are
   given for comparisons with Gyrophaena rousi Dvorak, 1966.
C1 Sert, Osman; Univ Hacettepe, Fac Sci, Ankara, TR-06800, Turkey, Turkey.
EM sert@hacettepe.edu.tr

   region; Eurasia

   concolor; Ischnopoda leucopus; Ischnopoda subaenea; Liogluta granigera
   [Turkey /  / New record]. 
   Gyrophaena cagatay [Turkey /  / New species].

   Staphylinidae

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF DICALLANEURA BUTLER (LEPIDOPTERA: LYCAENIDAE:
   RIODININAE) FROM PAPUA NEW GUINEA.
AU Lachlan, R.B.
   Mueller, Chris J. (chrismuller999@gmail.com) 
SO Australian Entomologist
VL 40
IS 4
PS 177-186
PD Nov 29 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Dicallaneura tennenti sp. n., from Western Province, Papua New Guinea,
   is described and illustrated. Characters are provided to distinguish it
   from the sympatric D. ribbei Rober, D. hyacinthus Toxopeus and D.
   pulchra (Guerin-Meneville).
